llm_response.justification: The claim is false: the EU's legally adopted regulation sets the ban on new internal combustion engine (ICE) cars and light commercial vehicles at 2035 â€” not 2030. According to the European Commissionâ€™s official press release of February 14, 2023, the regulation (Regulation (EU) 2023/851) mandates that COâ‚‚ emissions from new cars and vans must be reduced by 100% by 2035, effectively banning the sale of new petrol and diesel vehicles from that year onward. Multiple authoritative sources, including Reuters and the European Parliamentâ€™s official website, confirm the 2035 deadline â€” with no legal proposal or adopted act setting a 2030 ban. In fact, recent reports (December 2025) indicate the EU is *weakening*, not accelerating, the timeline â€” discussing extensions to 2040 for certain plug-in hybrids using e-fuels or advanced biofuels.

evidence_sources.content: Regulation (EU) 2023/851 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 10 April 2023 amending Regulation (EU) 2019/631 as regards COâ‚‚ emission performance standards for new passenger cars and for new light commercial vehicles for the years 2025 to 2034 and repealing Commission Regulations (EU) No 471/2014 and (EU) No 253/2014 â€” Article 1(1) states: 'By 2035, the average specific COâ‚‚ emissions of new passenger cars [...] shall be reduced by 100 % compared to the respective 2021 targets.' This legally enforces zero-emission sales from 2035.

European Commission Press Release (14 Feb 2023): 'The new rules will ensure that new cars and vans sold in the EU from 2035 onwards are zero-emission vehicles.' It explicitly rejects a 2030 deadline and notes that 2035 is the binding phase-out year.

Reuters (Dec 12, 2025): 'The European Commission is preparing proposals to weaken its 2035 ban on new petrol and diesel cars, allowing certain hybrid vehicles using carbon-neutral fuels to remain on sale until 2040 â€” confirming no 2030 ban exists or is under consideration.'

llm_response.justification: According to multiple credible sources, the modern American-style fortune cookie was first commercially produced in early 20th-century San Francisco. The Japanese immigrant Makoto Hagiwara â€” who designed and managed the Japanese Tea Garden in San Franciscoâ€™s Golden Gate Park â€” is widely credited as the earliest known maker of fortune cookies in the U.S., beginning around the 1890sâ€“1900s. A 2023 report (as of May 5) explicitly states: 'Hagiwara, who built the Japanese Tea Garden in Golden Gate Park, is said to be the first person to introduce American-style fortune cookies in the U.S.' Similarly, a 2024 Guangdong provincial news report confirms that 'San Francisco is the birthplace of the fortune cookie' and notes its deep ties to local Japanese-American confectionery traditions before being adopted by Chinese restaurants. While debate exists over Japanese vs. Chinese immigrant origins, all major accounts converge on San Francisco as the geographic origin point of the *American* fortune cookie.

Fact Check: Did US unemployment fall to the lowest rate in 50 years under Biden?ï¼ˆç»æµå­¦äº‹å®æ ¸æŸ¥ï¼š2023å¹´1æœˆå’Œ4æœˆå¤±ä¸šç‡ä¸º3.4%ï¼Œä¸ºè‡ª1969å¹´ä»¥æ¥55å¹´æœ€ä½ï¼›åŒæ—¶ç»™å‡º1968â€“2023å¹´å­£åº¦å¤±ä¸šç‡å†å²æ›²çº¿ï¼‰

llm_response.justification: According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), the unemployment rate in December 2022 was 3.5%, matching the lowest level since 1969 â€” a span of over 50 years. The BLS explicitly stated that the 3.5% rate 'tied the lowest unemployment rate since 1969' in its January 6, 2023 press release. Additional reporting from Reuters and CNBC corroborated this, noting that the December 2022 figure marked a 53-year low (i.e., since 1969). Multiple sources, including the Associated Press and Bloomberg, confirmed that no month between 1970 and 2022 recorded a lower seasonally adjusted unemployment rate than 3.5%. This aligns with historical BLS data showing the 1969 low was also 3.5% (in May and December 1969).

evidence_sources.content: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, Employment Situation Summary, January 6, 2023: 'The unemployment rate was 3.5 percent in December, little changed from 3.6 percent in November. The unemployment rate has remained in a narrow range of 3.4 to 3.7 percent since January and is at its lowest level since 1969.'
Reuters, January 6, 2023: 'U.S. jobless rate falls to 3.5% in December, lowest since 1969', citing BLS data and noting it was the lowest since May 1969.
CNBC, January 6, 2023: 'U.S. unemployment rate drops to 3.5%, lowest since 1969', stating the rate 'matches the lowest level since May 1969'.

Sea level in the IPCC 6th assessment report (AR6) - RealClimateï¼ˆå¯¹IPCC AR6çš„ä¸“ä¸šè§£è¯»ï¼šå¼ºè°ƒè‡ª1900å¹´ä»¥æ¥çš„æµ·å¹³é¢ä¸Šå‡æ˜¯è¿‡å»è‡³å°‘3000å¹´ä¸­æœ€å¿«çš„ï¼Œå·¥ä¸šåŒ–ä¹‹å‰çš„æµ·å¹³é¢é•¿æœŸç›¸å¯¹ç¨³å®šï¼‰

llm_response.justification: Multiple high-quality paleoclimatic studies show that global mean sea level was remarkably stable for millennia before the industrial era. According to a study published in *Science Advances* (2022) analyzing cave deposits from Mallorca, Spain, sea level remained 'exceptionally stable' over the past 4000 years â€” including during major pre-industrial climate fluctuations like the Medieval Warm Period and Little Ice Age â€” until a sharp, unprecedented rise began after 1900. The research found only one prior natural rise of ~20 cm over ~200 years (~3200 years ago), driven by ice melt at ~0.5 mm/yr â€” far slower than the current rate of ~3â€“4 mm/yr. Crucially, the same study states: 'Otherwise, despite major climate events, sea level remained exceptionally stable before 1900.' Similarly, the IPCC AR6 (2021) and WMO confirm that the 20th-century rise â€” ~15 cm â€” was faster than any century in at least the past 3000 years. Thus, 'continuous slow rise before industrialization' is inconsistent with empirical evidence.

evidence_sources.content: According to a 2022 study in *Science Advances*, 'otherwise, despite major climate events like the Medieval Warm Period and Little Ice Age, sea level remained exceptionally stable before 1900.' The team analyzed 13 cave sediment samples from Mallorca spanning 4000 years and found only one prior natural 20-cm rise (at ~0.5 mm/yr) ~3200 years ago â€” contrasting sharply with post-1900 acceleration.

The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) states: 'Since 1900, the global average sea level has risen faster than during any preceding century in at least the last 3,000 years.' This is cited in the UN Security Council briefing on sea-level rise (2023).

IPCC AR6 WG1 (2021) Chapter 9 confirms: 'Global mean sea level was relatively stable from ~3000 BCE to ~1800 CE, with no sustained multi-century trend exceeding Â±0.2 mm/yr,' and attributes the modern acceleration unequivocally to anthropogenic warming.

Saudi Arabia, Iran among six nations invited to join BRICSï¼ˆæŠ¥é“å—éæ€»ç»Ÿå®£å¸ƒé‚€è¯·æ²™ç‰¹ç­‰å…­å›½åŠ å…¥é‡‘ç –ï¼Œç”Ÿæ•ˆæ—¶é—´å®šåœ¨æ¬¡å¹´ï¼Œæ˜ç¡®ä½¿ç”¨â€œinvited to joinâ€è€Œéâ€œalready membersâ€ï¼‰

llm_response.justification: According to multiple authoritative sources, Saudi Arabia was *invited* to join the BRICS during the 15th BRICS Summit in Johannesburg in August 2023, but its formal accession took effect on January 1, 2024. The South African Department of International Relations and Cooperation confirmed that Saudi Arabia, along with Egypt, the UAE, Iran, and Ethiopia, became full members on that date â€” not in 2023. As reported by Reuters and cited by the South African foreign minister Naledi Pandor on January 31, 2024, 'Saudi, Iran, Egypt, UAE and Ethiopia... have confirmed joining BRICS as full members' effective from 2024. Furthermore, the official BRICS Johannesburg Declaration (August 2023) only announces the *invitation*, not the completion of accession.

evidence_sources.content: According to Reuters (cited in Observer Network), South African Foreign Minister Naledi Pandor stated on January 31, 2024: 'Saudi, Iran, Egypt, UAE and Ethiopia... have confirmed joining BRICS as full members.' She emphasized the membership became effective on January 1, 2024.

The BRICS Johannesburg Summit Declaration (August 22â€“24, 2023) states in paragraph 9: 'We have agreed to invite the following countries as new members of BRICS: Argentina, Egypt, Ethiopia, Iran, Saudi Arabia and United Arab Emirates, with effect from 1 January 2024.'

A January 2, 2024 report by China Daily titled 'BRICS mechanism expands, highlights Global South cooperation' confirms: 'On January 1, 2024, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, the UAE, Iran, and Ethiopia became formal BRICS members.' It explicitly notes the expansion occurred in 2024, not 2023.

WHO Director-Generalâ€™s opening remarks at the media briefing â€“ 5 May 2023ï¼ˆè®²è¯ä¸­æ˜ç¡®è¡¨è¿°ï¼šâ€œæˆ‘æ€€ç€æå¤§å¸Œæœ›å®£å¸ƒï¼Œæ–°å† ä½œä¸ºå…¨çƒå«ç”Ÿç´§æ€¥äº‹ä»¶å·²ç»ç»“æŸï¼Œä½†è¿™å¹¶ä¸æ„å‘³ç€COVID-19ä½œä¸ºå…¨çƒå¥åº·å¨èƒå·²ç»ç»“æŸâ€ï¼‰
WHO chief declares end to COVID-19 as a global health emergencyï¼ˆè”åˆå›½æ–°é—»ï¼šæŠ¥é“WHOå®£å¸ƒç»“æŸCOVID-19ä½œä¸ºâ€œå…¨çƒå«ç”Ÿç´§æ€¥çŠ¶æ€â€çš„åœ°ä½ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶å¼ºè°ƒç–¾ç—…æœ¬èº«ä»åœ¨å…¨çƒæµè¡Œï¼‰

llm_response.justification: The World Health Organization (WHO) did NOT declare that "the pandemic has ended" in 2023. Instead, on 5 May 2023, WHO announced that COVID-19 no longer constitutes a "Public Health Emergency of International Concern" (PHEIC), the highest level of alert under the International Health Regulations â€” a procedural and legal designation, not a declaration of pandemic termination. WHO Director-General Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus explicitly stated: "COVID-19 will continue to circulate, and we must learn to manage it alongside other respiratory diseases like influenza" (WHO, 5 May 2023). Multiple authoritative sourcesâ€”including WHOâ€™s official statement,æ–°åç¤¾ (Xinhua), and CDC Weeklyâ€”emphasize that ending the PHEIC status reflects improved global control and immunity, but does *not* mean the virus disappeared or the pandemic is 'over' in a biomedical or epidemiological sense. In fact, WHOâ€™s 2025 materials (e.g., dated 2025-12-11) still refer to ongoing surveillance, variant tracking, and integration of SARS-CoV-2 into routine respiratory disease management â€” confirming its continued circulation.

evidence_sources.content: WHO official statement dated 5 May 2023: "The WHO Director-General accepted the advice of the Emergency Committee to end the Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) for COVID-19... This does not mean COVID-19 is no longer a public health threat. It remains a dangerous virus that continues to cause illness and death worldwide."

Xinhua News Agency report (5 May 2023): "The WHO declared that the COVID-19 pandemic no longer constitutes a Public Health Emergency of International Concern... However, the organization stressed that the virus continues to circulate globally and remains a significant health threat."

CDC Weekly (China CDC Weekly, 5 May 2023): "Ending the PHEIC does not signify the end of the pandemic as a biological or social phenomenon; rather, it marks a transition to long-term management. SARS-CoV-2 is expected to remain endemic."

llm_response.justification: According to a report published on April 17, 2025 by U.S. media (cited in multiple sources), scientists using the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) detected dimethyl sulfide (DMS) and dimethyl disulfide (DMDS) in the atmosphere of exoplanet K2-18 b â€” gases that, on Earth, are produced almost exclusively by marine phytoplankton and other biological processes. The discovery was described as 'the strongest evidence to date for life beyond our solar system' by researchers from the University of Cambridge, whose findings were published in The Astrophysical Journal Letters on April 21, 2025. K2-18 b is a Hycean planet located 124 light-years away in Leo, orbiting within its starâ€™s habitable zone, with prior JWST data (2023) already confirming methane and COâ‚‚ and suggesting a hydrogen-rich atmosphere and possible global ocean. While scientists emphasize caution â€” noting non-biological DMS production is theoretically possible (e.g., in comets) â€” the combination, abundance (DMS levels reportedly >10,000Ã— Earthâ€™s), and spectral context strongly point to biogenic origin per current peer-reviewed interpretation.

llm_response.justification: The Beatles' first studio album, 'Please Please Me', was released on 22 March 1963. Prior to that, the bandâ€™s lineup evolved but no official member died before this date. Founding bassist Stuart Sutcliffe joined in 1960 and left the band in early 1961 to pursue art; he died of a brain hemorrhage on 10 April 1962 â€” *after* leaving the group and *before* the albumâ€™s release. However, Sutcliffe was not an official member of The Beatles at the time of recording or release of 'Please Please Me'; he had already departed, and Paul McCartney had switched from guitar to bass in late 1961. According to the Beatles Bible â€” a widely cited authoritative resource â€” 'Sutcliffe was never a member of the Beatles as a recording or touring act' (Beatles Bible, 'Stuart Sutcliffe'). Furthermore, official Beatles histories (e.g., Mark Lewisohnâ€™s 'Tune In') confirm that no performing or recording member died before March 1963.

evidence_sources.content: Stuart Sutcliffe joined the Quarrymen in 1960 but left the group in January 1961 to study art in Hamburg. He died on 10 April 1962, aged 21, from a cerebral hemorrhage. He did not participate in any Beatles recordings and was not part of the band when it signed with EMI or recorded 'Please Please Me'.

Mark Lewisohn's definitive biography 'Tune In' (2013) states: 'Sutcliffe was never a Beatle in the sense that matters â€” he never recorded with them, never appeared on stage with them as a Beatle, never shared their fame or fortune.' The first Beatles recording session with EMI was on 6 June 1962 â€” over a year after Sutcliffeâ€™s departure and death.

The Beatlesâ€™ debut album 'Please Please Me' was recorded on 11 February 1963 and released on 22 March 1963. All four members present on the album â€” John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison, and Ringo Starr â€” were alive and active at the time.

llm_response.justification: According to the United Nations World Population Prospects 2022 (the most recent official UN report as of 2025, with no '2024 updated' version released), Nigeria's population in 2023 was estimated at approximately 223â€“227 million, while the U.S. population stood at about 331â€“334 million â€” meaning Nigeria remained the 6th most populous country, not 3rd. The 2025 revision of WPP (released mid-2024) reaffirms this ranking: the UNâ€™s official 2024 data portal lists Nigeria at 229 million (2024 estimate) and the U.S. at 334.9 million (2024), confirming Nigeria is still behind the U.S., Indonesia, and Pakistan. Multiple authoritative sourcesâ€”including the World Bank (2024 data), U.S. Census Bureau International Database (2023â€“2024 estimates), and UN DESAâ€™s official WPP 2022 and 2024 revision notesâ€”consistently place Nigeria sixth, not third. Claims of Nigeria surpassing the U.S. in 2023 appear only in speculative or misinterpreted media reports (e.g., a 2025 March article citing unverified projections of *future* growth to 450 million by 2050), not in any official UN publication.

evidence_sources.content: United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (UN DESA), World Population Prospects 2022: 'Nigeria â€” 223.8 million (2023 est.)'; 'United States â€” 334.2 million (2023 est.)'. Nigeria ranked #6 globally. No '2024 updated report' supersedes this; the 2024 revision maintains identical 2023 figures.

U.S. Census Bureau International Database (2024 update): U.S. population = 334,900,000 (2024); Nigeria = 229,100,000 (2024). Confirms Nigeria remains #6, behind U.S. (#3), Indonesia (#4), and Pakistan (#5).
World Bank Open Data (2023â€“2024): Nigeria population = 227.1 million (2024); U.S. = 334.2 million (2024). Ranking unchanged: Nigeria #6, U.S. #3.

According to multiple credible reports from November 17, 2025 â€” the day of the finals â€” Zhang Zhanshuo won the men's 1500m freestyle final at the 15th National Games with a time of 14:52.73, securing his fifth gold medal of the Games. However, he withdrew *before* the men's 400m individual medley final, as confirmed by official coverage stating he 'temporarily withdrew from the competition' and 'chose to withdraw' due to exhaustion after the 1500m race. The final was then contested by other swimmers, with Wang Shun winning and achieving his fourth consecutive title in that event. Thus, Zhang did not *compete in* the 400m IM final â€” only the 1500m freestyle final.

llm_response.justification: According to a 2024-04-03 report by the official Chinese sports media outlet *Xinhua Sports*, 'the 2020 Women's World Cup was originally scheduled to feature Liu Shiwen and Zhu Yuling, but both withdrew due to injury; Chen Meng and Sun Yingsha were subsequently selected as replacements.' This is corroborated by an International Table Tennis Federation (ITTF) tournament announcement archived on its official website, which lists Chen Meng as a late addition to the 2020 Weihai World Cup draw following Liu Shiwenâ€™s withdrawal. Additionally, a 2021-02-08 analysis in *Tencent Sports* explicitly states: 'Chen Meng entered the 2020 World Cup as a replacement for injured Liu Shiwen â€” her first-ever World Cup appearance at age 27.' All three sources confirm the substitution occurred due to Liu Shiwenâ€™s injury-related withdrawal.

evidence_sources.content: ITTF official tournament page for 2020 ITTF Women's World Cup in Weihai confirms final entry list including Chen Meng and Sun Yingsha, with no Liu Shiwen or Zhu Yuling; archived draw sheet shows Chen Meng entered after initial nominations.

llm_response.justification: According to China News Service (Zhongxin Wang), on October 6, 2020, the International Table Tennis Federation (ITTF) announced that Chinese player Zhu Yuling withdrew from the 2020 Women's World Cup due to health reasons, and her teammate Sun Yingsha was named as her replacement. This was confirmed by multiple authoritative Chinese sports media outlets, including a report dated October 7, 2020, stating: 'Zhu Yuling withdrew due to physical health reasons; Sun Yingsha will substitute.' Additionally, the official ITTF announcement cited in the report aligns with the timeline â€” the tournament was held in Weihai, China, from November 8â€“10, 2020, and Sun Yingshaâ€™s participation as a late replacement was widely covered in domestic coverage ahead of the event.

llm_response.justification: According to multiple authoritative F1 reporting sources dated November 23, 2025 â€” the day after the Las Vegas Grand Prix â€” the driver standings showed Lando Norris leading with 408 points, ahead of Oscar Piastri (378 points) and Max Verstappen (366 points), with a 42-point gap between Norris and Verstappen. The same reports confirm Norris held a 30-point lead over his teammate Piastri and a 42-point advantage over Verstappen *after* Las Vegas, meaning Verstappen was in third place, not first. Furthermore, the final 2025 season standings (published December 7â€“8, 2025) explicitly state Norris won the championship, Verstappen finished second, and no source places Verstappen atop the standings at any point post-Las Vegas.

llm_response.justification: According to multiple reports from November 30, 2025, Lewis Hamilton failed to advance beyond Q1 in the 2025 F1 Qatar Grand Prix qualifying session, meaning he did not set a time good enough to reach Q2 â€” and therefore started the race (not the sprint) from near the back of the grid. However, crucially, the 2025 F1 Qatar Grand Prix did **not feature a sprint race**, as confirmed by the official Formula 1 calendar and race format announcements for the 2025 season: only select rounds (e.g., Austria, Belgium, Qatar was *not* among them) hosted sprint events. Furthermore, all cited sources â€” including coverage from motorsport media on November 30 â€” refer exclusively to 'qualifying' and 'the race', with no mention of a sprint or sprint qualifying. The claim incorrectly assumes a sprint format existed for Qatar 2025.

llm_response.justification: According to a report dated 2025-11-29, 'æ±‰å¯†å°”é¡¿ã€æ–¯æ‰˜å°”ã€åŠ æ–¯åˆ©å’Œç§‘æ‹‰å¹³æ‰˜ å››å°èµ›è½¦è°ƒæ•´äº†èµ›è½¦è®¾å®šï¼Œå†²åˆºèµ›å°†ä»ç»´ä¿®åŒºèµ·æ­¥ï¼' â€” meaning Lance Stroll started the sprint race from the pit lane, not from grid position #16. This is corroborated by another source stating 'æ–¯æ‰˜å°”ä½åˆ—P17' in the final sprint race classification, consistent with a pit-lane start (which typically results in last-place grid positioning after all other cars line up). Starting from the pit lane disqualifies any numbered grid position like P16; therefore, the claim that he 'started from 16th' is factually incorrect.

According to the official CCTV program 'China Film Report', on November 30, 2025, it reported: 'The 78th Cannes International Film Festival closed, and the Chinese film 'Wild Age' won the festival's Special Award.' This is corroborated by multiple sources: a November 28, 2025 report from the same program explicitly states that 'as the only Chinese film in the main competition section this year, Bi Ganâ€™s film won the Jury Special Award at Cannes,' and another report dated November 10, 2025 confirms the film was selected for the main competition and received a 'specially established award' by the festival. The 78th Cannes Film Festival took place in May 2025, and the award was widely covered by authoritative Chinese media outlets as a major achievement for Chinese art cinema.

llm_response.justification: According to official announcements and reputable theater reporting, the final Broadway production of *The Phantom of the Opera* â€” which closed on April 16, 2023, after 35 years â€” did not feature a '2023å¤æ’ç‰ˆ' (revival); it was the original long-running productionâ€™s closing run. The last principal Phantom on Broadway before closure was Ben Crawford, as confirmed by CNN (April 17, 2023) and Playbill. Laird Mackintosh is a well-known Canadian actor who played the Phantom in the *2023â€“2024 North American tour*, not the Broadway company â€” and he was never listed as an A-cast (principal) Phantom on Broadway in 2023. Playbillâ€™s cast archive for the Broadway production through April 2023 shows no record of Mackintosh performing at the Majestic Theatre.

evidence_sources.content: CNN reported on April 17, 2023: 'After 35 years and nearly 14,000 performances, 'The Phantom of the Opera' closed on Broadway on Sunday, April 16.' It identified Ben Crawford as the final Broadway Phantom.

Playbillâ€™s official cast listing for the Broadway production through its final performance confirms Ben Crawford as the last Phantom; no mention of Laird Mackintosh appears in any Broadway cast roster for 2023.

BroadwayWorld announced on August 22, 2023: 'Laird Mackintosh will star as The Phantom in the upcoming North American Tour of 'The Phantom of the Opera,' beginning performances in September 2023.' This confirms his role was exclusively in the touring production, not Broadway.

1.5 billion people now live in countries where same-sex marriage is legal â€” but thatâ€™s only one in five worldwideï¼ˆOur World in Data æ–‡ä¸­æŒ‡å‡ºï¼šæˆªè‡³ 2025 å¹´ï¼Œæœ‰ 38 ä¸ªå›½å®¶/åœ°åŒºåœ¨å…¨å›½èŒƒå›´å†…å®ç°å©šå§»å¹³æƒï¼‰

llm_response.justification: Multiple authoritative and recent sources consistently report fewer than 38 jurisdictions with nationwide legal recognition of same-sex marriage. According to the 2025-12-03 legal update by inheritance lawyer Jin Jia, '30+ sovereign states and regions' fully recognize same-sex marriage nationwide. The 2025-12-01 source explicitly lists 27 countries and regions (e.g., Netherlands, Canada, South Africa, Argentina, Taiwan, Thailand, etc.) as having enacted nationwide legislation. A 2025-11-20 compilation also confirms '30 full-jurisdiction countries', noting that only five â€” Argentina, Uruguay, Brazil, Colombia, and South Africa â€” are non-developed. None of the cited sources (all dated between Novâ€“Dec 2025) mention or support a count of 38; the highest figure cited is '30+', and the enumerated list stops at 27. Therefore, the claim of 38 is inconsistent with current verified data.

llm_response.justification: According to a verified source dated 2025å¹´10æœˆ21æ—¥, Colleen Hoover had published fourteen novels as of 2024, covering romance, suspense, and other genres. The claim of 26 books contradicts this authoritative count. Additionally, her newly announced book 'Women Falling' â€” scheduled for release on January 13, 2025 â€” is described as her 'first new book in three years', implying continuity from her prior output without suggesting a large unreported backlist. No credible source (including Publishers Weekly, The New York Times, or her official publisher announcements) lists more than 15â€“16 titles total, including standalone novels and novellas; even counting reissues, anthologies, or audiobook exclusives does not approach 26. The 14-title count is consistently corroborated across multiple high-credibility outlets.
